https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S246882311730024X/mmc1/MAIN/application/msword/97d919aa9fef2c1e077044ed249faeb1/mmc1.docx https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/pii:S246882311730024X/mmc1/MAIN/application/msword/97d919aa9fef2c1e077044ed249faeb1/mmc1.docx mmc1 mmc1.docx docx 5333035 APPLICATION MCAT 103 S2468-8231(17)30024-X 10.1016/j.mcat.2017.01.029 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Molecular structure of iridium complex 1 (Cp*=pentamethylcyclopentadienyl). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Oxygen evolution plots for iridium complex 1 (0.5mM) in 5mL MiliQ H2O with Oxone (90mM per round). Oxone was directly added to the reaction mixture formed in the last round. The time gap between each round is at least 4h. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 UV–vis spectra of the reaction mixture of complex 1 (1mM) with different amounts of Oxone. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 1H NMR spectra of the reaction mixture of complex 1 (1mM) with different amounts of Oxone (from bottom to top: 0, 4, 10, 20 and 40 equiv). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 MALDI-MS spectra of reaction mixture of complex 1 with 40 (left), 60 (middle) and 40×2 (right) equiv Oxone. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Proposed structure for the blue species (m/z =461.3/463.3). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 17O NMR spectra of Oxone (200mM) in 10% 17OH2 (bottom) and reaction mixture of 1 (5mM) oxidized with Oxone (200mM) in 10% 17OH2 (top). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 MALDI-MS spectra of reaction mixture of complex 1 with 40+60 (left) and 40×3 (right) equiv Oxone. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 MALDI-MS spectrum of the reaction mixture of complex 1 with 40×4 equiv Oxone. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Proposed structure for the main ingredient in the purple species (m/z =340.6/342.6/344.6). Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Proposed structure for the aqua iridium dimer in the purple species (m/z =574.6/576.6/578.6). Fig. 11 Fig. 12 17O NMR spectrum of reaction mixture of 1 (2.5mM) oxidized with Oxone (200×4mM) in 10% 17OH2. Fig. 12 Editor's choice paper Transformation of a Cp*-iridium carbene catalyst in water oxidation using Oxone as primary oxidant Hui Cao Jing-Fan Zhang Quan Zhou Shuang Huang Xi Hong Xiu-Feng Hou ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Shanghai, 200433, China Department of Chemistry Fudan University Shanghai 200433 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Fundamental understanding of the real catalytic species in water oxidation is a major knowledge gap that must be overcome in order to develop artificial water splitting systems and produce chemical fuels from solar energy. In an effort to analyze the transformation and catalytic resting state of [Cp*Ir(pmNHC)Cl]Cl [pmNHC=1-(2-pyrimidyl)-3-n-butylimidazol-2-ylidene, Cp*=pentamethylcyclopentadienyl] in water oxidation using potassium peroxymonosulfate (Oxone) as primary oxidant, we found the precatalyst evolved into blue solution when a small amount of Oxone was added while further oxidation yield purple solution. These species have been proven to be homogeneous and they remain active in water oxidation. 1H NMR profiles and MALDI-MS data suggested a rapid oxidation of the Cp* ligand to acetone, formic and acetic acid. 1H NMR, TEM-EDX as well as MALDI-MS data indicated a continuous degradation of pyrimidyl, butyl and NHC groups. MALDI-MS, XANES and 17O NMR spectroscopy data of the blue species are most consistent with an iridium(III) compound with two waters, one dioxygen and pmNHC group. The catalytic resting purple species probably consists of an iridium(III) complex with three waters, one chloride and one bicarbonate ligand. Besides, the presence of a small amount of iridium aqua ion oligomers was observed in the purple species. The formation of polymers and nanoparticles is likely to be inhibited by the acid environment. Keywords Oxone Water oxidation Iridium Carbene Transformation Introduction Cp* iridium complexes (Cp*=C5Me5 −) have recently been shown as effective precatalysts for the oxidation of water to molecular oxygen [1–7], which is recognized as the most challenging process in the realization of artificial photosynthesis aimed at producing solar fuels [8–14]. Among these water oxidation catalysts (WOCs), robust iridium N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ones are especially promising [15–23], such as the largest TON (turnover number) ever reported for a metal-catalyzed water oxidation reaction [19]. Although much effort has been dedicated to the development of novel and better performing Ir-WOCs, the reaction mechanism and the catalytic species remain unclear. Clearly, Ir-WOCs can undergo oxidative transformation under harsh experimental conditions. To distinguish between a homogeneous or heterogeneous catalytic species, different methods such as kinetic isotope effect investigations, electrochemical quartz crystal nanobalance (EQCN) and dynamic light scaterring (DLS) have been used, and the results are still a matter of debate [24–28]. An interesting example, in this aspect, is reported by Fukuzumi [27], who studied the transformation of [Cp*Ir(4,4′-R2-2,2′-bipy)(H2O)]X2 (bipy=bipyridine) in water oxidation using cerium ammonium nitrate (CAN) as the sacrificial oxidant (SO). Clear evidence for the formation of Ir(OH)3 nanoparticles (Nps) by complete degradation of Cp* and bipy ligands was found when R=OH whereas in other cases (R=OMe, Me or COOH) the catalysis is likely homogeneous. Recently Lloret-Fillol [19] studied the possibility of Nps in water oxidation with [Cp*Ir(NHC)X2] using CAN and NaIO4 as SO. DLS experiments showed no evidence for Np formation in the catalytic reaction of Ir precatalyst with NaIO4. However, Nps with sizes bigger than 10nm were detected in the case of CAN. These results suggest the crucial role of ligand and SO in directing the transformation of the precatalyst towards a homogeneous molecular species or heterogeneous Nps. Homogeneous water oxidation systems are obviously more amenable to mechanistic investigation and systematic fine-tuning than metal-oxides [29,30]. Although some homogeneous catalytic species are remarkably stable, isolation of them from its native aqueous solution in pure form, however, is quite difficult.31 Spectroscopic investigation on the aqueous solution is used instead to gain insight into transformation process and active species. The oxidation of Cp* ligand to acetic and formic acid in water oxidation has been widely reported [19,31], and Macchioni [32–34] has demonstrated the detailed degradation process of Cp* ligand by 1H NMR and ESI-MS. The degradation of other ligands on homogeneous Ir-WOCs like substituents at the nitrogen atoms of the carbene has also been reported [19]. Recently, Crabtree et al. [31] presented spectroscopic evidence that led to the first characterization of homogeneous blue species originated from iridium-catalyzed water oxidation driven by NaIO4. Their results suggested that [Cp*Ir(pyalc)OH] (pyalc=2-(2′pyridyl)-2-propanolate) precatalyst evolved to a Cp*-free dicationic [IrIV(pyalc)(H2O)2(μ-O)]2 complex as the blue resting species. During our investigation of a Cp*-iridium NHC catalyst in water oxidation using Oxone as SO, we found the precatalyst would evolve to a blue species when a small amount of Oxone was added. Further addition of Oxone would yield stable purple species, while previous studies on iridium-catalyzed water oxidation all pointed out the formation of blue solution as catalytic resting state [25,28]. DLS results indicated these catalytic species to be homogeneous. 1H NMR, TEM-EDX and MALDI-MS results suggested a gradual oxidation of ligands. Possible structures of blue and purple species were then proposed based on these results along with XANES and 17O NMR data. Results and Discussion Water oxidation using Oxone as primary oxidant We investigated iridium NHC complex 1 (Fig. 1 ) and some other iridium complexes (Fig. S1 in Supplementary material) for water oxidation employing Oxone (KHSO5·0.5 K2SO4·0.5KHSO4) as oxidant. Oxone has previously been used as the chemical oxidant for water oxidation with manganese complexes [35–38], calcium manganese oxides [39] and very recently, iron complexes [40]. The oxidation potential of Oxone is 1.82V vs NHE, which provides a moderate thermal potential for water oxidation [35]. Iridium complex 1 was first evaluated as a water oxidation catalyst with Oxone as oxidant (Fig. 2 ). To our surprise, oxygen evolving rate was extremely slow after addition of 180 equivalent Oxone (90mM) to the aqueous solution of complex 1 (0.5mM). Meanwhile, the precatalyst turned to blue solution for about four hours before evolving to purple solution. Further addition of Oxone to this purple solution, however, led to fast oxygen evolving. The results of stepwise reaction showed the purple species could serve as an efficient catalyst for 7 rounds with no significant activity decrease until the reaction system became a thick suspension due to solubility of salts. The overall TON (turnover number, TON=n(O2)/n(catalyst)) is 687 and the average TOF (turnover frenquncy, TOF=TON·H−1, evaluated at 50% conversion) after the first round is about 24h−1. Besides, no visible solids were observed in the catalytic process. The activity and stability of complex 1 were also evaluated with CAN (Fig. S2 in Supplementary material) and NaIO4 (Fig. S3 in Supplementary material), two reported sacrificial oxidants. After addition of CAN to the aqueous solution of complex 1, oxygen was generated quickly. However, insoluble solids possibly resulted from catalyst degradation [41] started to appear at the same time, which lowered the catalytic activity and made the second round reaction incomplete. As previously observed for other Cp*Ir complexes in WO using NaIO4, iridium complex 1 turned into a homogeneous blue species which served as an efficient WOC in the next 7 rounds before inefficient stirring. The overall TON is 702 and the average TOF after the first round is about 330h−1. These results showed the crucial role of sacrificial oxidants in determining the transformation process of iridium catalysts. The gaseous product of water oxidation using Oxone has been characterized as pure oxygen by GC–MS. The 18O-labeling experiments showed that the O atoms in O2 were derived from both water and Oxone due to rapid oxo exchange between them (Fig. S4 and Table S1 in Supplementary material). The presence of nanoparticles in water oxidation with complex 1 has been excluded by DLS, suggesting a homogenous catalytic process (Fig. S5 in Supplementary material). Variation of iridium and Oxone concentration showed the rate of the stable reaction to be first-order dependent on both [Ir] and oxidant, at least in high concentrations (Figs. S6, S7 in Supplementary material). The first-order dependence of reaction rate on Oxone concentration suggested the oxidation of iridium catalyst to be the rate-determining step, which is consistent with former reports on WO with CAN and NaIO4 [42]. These results suggested Oxone to be a mild chemical oxidant for iridium-catalyzed water oxidation. Its relatively low TOF number is probably due to the acidity (pH around 2) of reaction solution [43] and could be favorable for detailed investigation on stepwise catalyst transformation. Since the transformation towards purple species was also observed for other active iridium complexes in WO driven by Oxone (Figs. S8–S11 in Supplementary material), complex 1 was chosen to investigate the transformation of homogeneous iridium catalysts. Oxidative transformation of iridium complex 1 UV-vis spectroscopy was first used to monitor the transformation process of complex 1 (Figs. 3 and S12 ). We found that iridium complex 1 would turn into a blue species after addition of 40 equiv Oxone and could remain stable in air if no more oxidant was added. The characteristic absorption band of the blue species in UV–vis spectrum is at 576nm, which is a little apart from previous reports on blue solution evolved from Ir-WOCs (∼600nm). Another 40 equiv oxidant into the blue solution would yield a purple solution with absorption band moving from 576nm to 529nm. The solution remained purple after further addition of Oxone with absorption band moving slightly to 513nm and staying there afterwards. UV–vis spectra suggested that the precatalyst reached catalytic resting state after 4 times addition of 40 equiv Oxone. 1H NMR analysis showed a rapid disappearance of the Cp* signal and other characteristic signals of iridium complex 1 (Fig. 4 ). Acetone (2.21ppm), acetaldehyde (2.28ppm), formic (8.23ppm), acetic (2.08ppm) and glycolic acid (4.48ppm) were identified, which is consistent with a lot of reports on Cp* degradation under oxidative conditions [31–34,44]. No signals from partially oxidized complex 1 or other organic fragments were detected, but some splits and broadened peaks of the pyrimidine and NHC ligand remained visible in the spectrum of the blue species (Fig. S13 in Supplementary material). Splits of the original catalyst were barely visible for purple species (Fig. S14 in Supplementary material), indicating further degradation of the ligands or formation of paramagnetic iridium species. XAFS analysis (X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy) is a powerful in situ tool for gaining insight into transition metals in aqueous phase. The analysis of the edge position and shape of the spectra near the absorption edge (XANES) suggested the blue and purple iridium species were all in the iridium(III) oxidation state (Figs. S15, S16 in Supplementary material). These results ruled out the possibility of paramagnetic iridium complexes and suggested ligand degradation to be accountable for signal loss in 1H NMR. TEM-EDX analysis (transmission electron microscopy energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy) showed the presence of both carbon and nitrogen in the vacuum-dried samples of blue species (Fig. S17 in Supplementary material). Although carbon was not accurately quantifiable due to background from adventitious carbon, a close 4:1 ratio of N to Ir was found as indication for the retention of the chelate NHC ligand in the blue species. As for the vacuum-dried samples of purple species, the ratio of N and Ir declined as oxidation went further (Table S2). The decrease of N atom supported a decomposition process of the catalyst. MALDI-TOF-MS(+) analysis (matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry) revealed more structural information of these iridium species. No peaks above 1100 m/z were observed in these MALDI-MS spectra, which excludes the presence of high nuclearity clusters and is consistent with DLS results. Despite some unoxidized precatalyst (m/z =563.2/565.2) remaining in the reaction mixture of complex 1 with 40 equiv Oxone, a new group of peaks (m/z =461.2/463.2) was found in the blue solution (Fig. 5 , left and Fig. S18 in Supplementary material). The clear 3:5 ratio of the new peaks suggested its mononuclear structure. Considering the Cp* ligand should be oxidized and the chelating NHC ligand should be retained, we proposed a side-on dioxygen iridium(III) structure for the blue species (Fig. 6 ). The formation of d6 complexes with formula [M(L)4(O2)]+ (M=Co, Rh, Ir) containing η 2-coordinated dioxygen is well-known [45–49]. Dioxygen iridium complexes can usually be synthesized by reaction of molecular oxygen with corresponding iridium(I) complexes and some of them are air- and moisture-stable [50]. The characteristic absorption band of a dioxygen iridium complexes ( t BuPCP)IrO2 [ t BuPCP=κ3-C6H3(CH2P t Bu2)2] lies around 610nm in UV–vis spectrum [51], which is close to the absorption band of blue species giving consideration to their dramatically different structures. The 17O NMR spectrum of iridium complex 1 reacted with 40 equiv Oxone showed more information of oxygen atoms in the blue species (Fig. 7 ). The peak at 161.60ppm was identified as HSO4 − and SO4 2− by comparison with oxidant while no peroxyl group peak (150.24ppm) from original Oxone was found, providing spectroscopic evidence for KHSO5 acting as a net 2-electron acceptor when driving oxidation catalysis [35–40]. The sharp peak at 76.96ppm are consistent with Ir-aqua units [31,52] in our proposed structure. The broad signal at 257.26ppm represents acetic acid [31] resulted from Cp* degradation. There is a unique peak next to acetic acid at 261.95ppm which is slightly apart from the μ-oxo shift (265ppm) Crabtree [31] reported in blue solution evolved from iridium precatalyst in water oxidation with periodate. However, our MALDI-MS result pointed out, no doubt, the mononuclear nature of the blue species and thus ruled out the possibility of μ-oxo group in Oxone system. The peak at 261.95ppm most likely represents the side-on dioxygen [53]. The MALDI-MS spectra of the reaction mixture of complex 1 with 60 (Fig. 5, middle and Fig. S19) and 40×2 (Fig. 5, right and Fig. S20) equiv Oxone showed the presence of blue species (m/z =461.3/463.3) and two new groups of peaks at m/z 491.2/493.2 and 521.1/523.1 respectively. No more peaks at m/z 563.2/565.2/567.2 were detected in the latter spectrum, suggesting all the original complex 1 has been transformed after addition of 40 equiv Oxone twice. The proportion of blue species (m/z =461.3/463.3) went down while new species at m/z 491.2/493.2 and 521.1/523.1 accumulated as oxidation went further. This trend suggested a progressive transformation of the blue species to m/z 491.2/493.2 species and then to m/z 521.1/523.1 species. The m/z gap of 30 is probably caused by introduction of two oxygen atoms and loss of two hydrogen atoms, in another word, oxidation. The MALDI-MS spectra of the reaction mixture of complex 1 with 40+60 (Fig. 8 , left and Fig. S21) and 40×3 (Fig. 8, right and Fig. S22) equiv Oxone revealed a new transformation process of the iridium catalyst. Five new groups of peaks (m/z =433.2/435.2, 419.1/421.2, 405.1/407.1, 391.1/393.1 and 377.1/379.1) all with a clear 3:5 ratio showed the formation of a series of mononuclear iridium species. The transformation trend indicated a gradual loss of molecular weight with a precise gap of 14, which is the exact molecular weight of a CH2 group. Considering the existence of butyl group on the iridium catalyst and four gaps in the MALDI-MS spectra, it is very likely the butyl group undergoes a continuous oxidation during this transformation process. It should be noticed these m/z numbers indicated that pyrimidyl group underwent degradation before butyl group. If the pyrimidyl group remains intact in the m/z 433.2/435.2 iridium species whose butyl group is supposed to be unoxidized yet, the overall molecular weight of iridium and pmNHC is about 395, leaving molecular weight of about 40 for other ligands. In this case a stable pseudooctahedral iridium(III) structure would not be possible. The oxidative degradation of substituents at the nitrogen atoms of the carbene in catalytic water oxidation has also been reported by Lloret-Fillol when NaIO4 was used as oxidant [19]. They presented 1H NMR and GC–MS evidence for the formation of acetophenone when an iridium carbene catalyst with 1-phenylethyl substituent at the nitrogen atom of the carbene was used. As indicated by UV–vis spectra, the MALDI-MS spectra of the reaction mixture of complex 1 with 40×4 (Figs. 9 and S23 ) and 40×5 (Fig. S24 in Supplementary material) equiv Oxone showed the same groups of peaks with the exact same proportion, suggesting a final stable state. The MALDI-MS spectrum of further oxidized catalyst (40×10 equiv Oxone) showed no difference (Fig. S25 in Supplementary material). In the MALDI-MS spectrum of the final purple solution originated from reaction of complex 1 with 40×4 equiv Oxone, a main group of peaks at m/z 340.6/342.6/344.6 with a ratio of about 58:100:44 could be seen. The ratio is most closely to the composition of one iridium atom and one chloride atom. Since 1H NMR, EDX and MALDI-MS results above suggested a continuous degradation of Cp*, pyrimidyl and butyl groups, NHC group could very likely be next, leaving no original ligands on the iridium center. This might be the answer to the lack of peaks in 1H NMR and extremely low N atom percentage in EDX and XPS. The catalytic resting species (m/z 340.6/342.6/344.6) probably have three waters, one chloride and one bicarbonate ligand (Fig. 10 ). Bicarbonate and carbonic acid should be derived from oxidation of organic ligands on the iridium precatalyst. The formation of carbon dioxide in iridium-catalyzed water oxidation has been reported intensively. Besides, a wide variety of transition metals (Zn [54], Ni [55], Pd [56], Pt [57], Co [58], Cu [59], Re [60] et. al), including Ir [61], are known to form stable complexes with bicarbonate ligands. Very recently, experimental [62] and theoretical [63] analysis on electrocatalytic water oxidation with monomeric copper(II) complexes revealed the ancillary role of bicarbonate/carbonate ligand in OO bond formation. We also noticed several other groups of peaks in m/z 574.6/576.6/578.6, 808.6/810.6/812.6/814.6 and 1043.6/1044.6/1046.6/1048.6/1050.6. Their peak ratios are 9:30:25, 27:135:225:125 and 81:540:1350:1500:625 respectively, which are typical ratios for binuclear, trinuclear and tetranuclear iridium complexes. It is well known that the hydrolytic polymerization of metal aqua ions could occur through a combination of processes that are initiated on deprotonation of the aqua ion [64,65]. Our 1H NMR, EDX and MALDI-MS results have suggested a complete ligand degradation process, making iridium oligomer formation possible. Previous studies on oxidation of hexaaquairidium proved that this polymerization could happen under very acid conditions [66]. During this reaction, the color change of the Ir-containing solutions from blue to purple is believed to be caused by (not well-defined) oligomerization processes. These purple oligomer species have been reported with a characteristic absorption band at 494nm in UV–vis, which is close to 513nm since our system is more complex. The possible structure of the relatively abundant binuclear iridium complex is proposed in Fig. 11 . In order to verify the existence of iridium oligomers, change of the purple solution’s pH value was conducted. No change was observed when pH value declines while fast formation of purple solids was observed as pH increased, which is consistent with hydroxyl-promoted metal aqua ion oligomerization [67,68]. However, it is noteworthy that the proportion of iridium oligomers stayed at a very low amount and didn’t increase as oxidation went further. The acid environment probably inhibited massive iridium aqua ion oligomerization, which might be the answer to MALDI-MS results of no high nuclearity clusters and DLS results of no nanoparticles. The 17O NMR spectrum of iridium complex 1 reacted with 40×4 equiv Oxone (Fig. 12 ) showed HSO4 − and SO4 2− (161.60ppm), Ir-aqua units (77.01ppm), acetic acid (257.41ppm) and a small new peak at 282.42ppm which is likely to be coordinated bicarbonate ligand. Conclusion The homogeneous reaction of [Cp*Ir(pmNHC)Cl]Cl, a water-oxidation catalyst, with Oxone was studied to analyze possible oxidative transformation and catalytic species. NMR spectroscopy, EDX, XANES and MALDI-TOF-MS techniques provided evidence for the formation of a series of species with gradually oxidized ligands. Initially, a blue species probably with the structure of [Ir(pmNHC)(H2O)2O2]+ was formed with oxidation of the Cp* ligand. Further oxidation led to the continuous degradation of pyrimidine, butyl and NHC ligands and finally a stable purple species. This catalytic resting species consists of an iridium complex with a possible structure of [Ir(HCO3)(H2O)3Cl] + and also a small amount of iridium aqua ion oligomers. How the purple species functions as a homogeneous catalyst without organic ligands is still under research. It should be pointed out, however, the oxidative transformation process of a precatalyst in water oxidation varies dramatically as oxidant type, catalyst structure and reaction condition change. Experimental Section General procedure Cp*Ir(pmNHC)Cl]Cl (1) was synthesized according to literature procedure [69]. Syntheses were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques. Organic solvents were distilled under nitrogen from sodium benzophenone (toluene, diethyl ether) or calcium hydride (dichloromethane). Water (18MΩcm−1) was purified with a Milli-Q Millipore Gradient AIS system. Other chemical reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Preparation of Cp*Ir(pmNHC)Cl]Cl (1) N-(2-pyrimidyl)imidazole (146mg, 1.0mmol) was refluxed with 1-iodobutane (75μL, 1.1mmol) in toluene for 24h. After cooled to room temperature, it was filtered and the precipitate was washed with diethyl ether and dried under vacuum to afford the corresponding imidazolium iodide. To a solution of the imidazolium iodide (66mg, 0.2mmol) in 15mL dry CH2Cl2, Ag2O (23mg, 0.1mmol) was added in the absence of light and stirred under nitrogen for 6h. After the addition of [Cp*IrCl2]2 (70mg, 0.1mmol), the mixture was stirred overnight at room temperature in the dark. The precipitate was filtered off and the filtrate was concentrated under vacuum. The solid was purified by chromatography, eluted with CH2Cl2/MeOH (10:1) and precipitated in ether to yield complex 1 as a yellow solid. Yield: 62%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400MHz): δ 8.87–8.82 (m, 2H), 7.88 (d, 1H), 7.59 (t, 1H), 7.28–7.24 (m, 1H), 4.32–4.24 (m, 2H), 1.87 (m, 2H), 1.81 (s, 15H), 1.45–1.35 (m, 2H), 0.97 (t, 3H). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100MHz): δ 165.34, 161.22, 159.48, 157.68, 124.19, 121.30, 118.16, 93.00, 50.93, 32.99, 20.02, 13.97, 9.55. Catalytic gas-evolution experiments A vial containing an oxidant (CAN, NaIO4 or Oxone) aqueous solution was connected to one of the pressure transducer sensors under air atmosphere. The reaction was initiated by adding an aqueous solution of the catalyst by using a syringe through a septa. The oxygen evolution of the reaction was monitored by recording the headspace pressure increase (5s interval) and calibrated with GC-TCD. The variability of the O2 yield was typically less than 10%. Dynamic light scattering DLS was performed on a ZEN 3690 Zeta Sizer. The DLS instrument used in this study can detect particle sizes ranging from 0.1 to 10000nm. NMR measurement 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded at room temperature on either 400 or 500MHz Bruker Avance spectrometers and referenced to residual protio-solvent signals (δ in ppm). 17O NMR was performed on a 500MHz Bruker Avance spectrometer equipped with a 5mm ATMA broadband probe operating at 67.8MHz controlled through TopSpin (version 1.3). Samples were prepared by dissolving the solid reagents in 10% 17OH2 (Sigma-Aldrich) at least 15min prior to the analysis. Measurements were performed with sample spinning but without lock and sweep using the following parameters: p1=10μs, d1=100ms, aq=100ms, sw=1400ppm, ns=150.000. Spectra were manually phased and baseline corrected with apodization to 20Hz line broadening, and the free water line centered to 0ppm. UV–vis measurement UV–vis spectra were recorded at 1nm resolution on a Varian Cary 50 using 1.0cm quartz cuvettes against a background of neat solvent. EDX measurement EDX spectra were taken using a JEOL JEM 2100F 200kV TEM. Samples were prepared by evaporation of solvent, drying in high vacuum, and depositing the resulting bluish powder onto lacey carbon copper TEM grids (TedPella) as a suspension in dry ethanol. Peak deconvolutions were performed using TIA software. XAFS Data Collection The X-ray absorption data at the Ir LIII- edge of the samples were recorded at room temperature in transmission (for solid samples) or Lytle (for aqueous samples) mode using ion chambers or in the fluorescent mode with silicon drift fluorescence detector at beam line BL14W1 of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF), China. The station was operated with a Si (111) double crystal monochromator. During the measurement, the synchrotron was operated at energy of 3.5GeV and a current between 150–210mA. The photon energy was calibrated with the first inflection point of Ir LIII –edge in Ir metal foil. MALDI-TOF-MS measurement MALDI-TOF-MS investigation were performed using an IRMPD Module Ion Spec mass spectrometer with Ion Spec 99 software. An aqueous solution of iridium complex 1 (0.5mM) and certain amount of oxone was stirred for at least one day at 25°C, after which a 1μL aliquot was withdrawn and mixed with 99μL of matrix solution (18mM 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid in 1:1 MeOH/H2O). One microliter portions of the quenched mixture were spotted onto the MALDI target plate, dried in air, introduced to the HV chamber, and ionized with a New Wave laser at 355nm (250MHz). Spectra were acquired over the mass range 400–4500 m/z or 100–1500 m/z in reflector positive mode summing 2000 laser shots. Conflict of interest The authors declare no competing financial interest. MH2014-07) is gratefully acknowledged. The authors thank beamline BL14W1 (Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility) for providing the beam time. coredata.dc:description: Fundamental understanding of the real catalytic species in water oxidation is a major knowledge gap that must be overcome in order to develop artificial water splitting systems and produce chemical fuels from solar energy. In an effort to analyze the transformation and catalytic resting state of [Cp*Ir(pmNHC)Cl]Cl [pmNHC=1-(2-pyrimidyl)-3-n-butylimidazol-2-ylidene, Cp*=pentamethylcyclopentadienyl] in water oxidation using potassium peroxymonosulfate (Oxone) as primary oxidant, we found the precatalyst evolved into blue solution when a small amount of Oxone was added while further oxidation yield purple solution. These species have been proven to be homogeneous and they remain active in water oxidation. 1H NMR profiles and MALDI-MS data suggested a rapid oxidation of the Cp* ligand to acetone, formic and acetic acid. 1H NMR, TEM-EDX as well as MALDI-MS data indicated a continuous degradation of pyrimidyl, butyl and NHC groups. MALDI-MS, XANES and 17O NMR spectroscopy data of the blue species are most consistent with an iridium(III) compound with two waters, one dioxygen and pmNHC group. The catalytic resting purple species probably consists of an iridium(III) complex with three waters, one chloride and one bicarbonate ligand. Besides, the presence of a small amount of iridium aqua ion oligomers was observed in the purple species. The formation of polymers and nanoparticles is likely to be inhibited by the acid environment.
coredata.dc:title: Transformation of a Cp*-iridium carbene catalyst in water oxidation using Oxone as primary oxidant
